Name: Hanying's Reversed Pipa
Desc: Influenced by the cultural exchanges and fusion on the ancient Silk Road, Dunhuang murals feature various elements related to music and dancing, including pipa, flutes, konghou, and drums. Among the instruments, pipa is most frequently depicted in the murals and stands out the most in terms of its artistic expression. A classic Dunhuang mural in Mogao Cave 112 depicts a unique way of playing pipaâ€”the entertainer plays the pipa behind her back with extraordinary techniques.

Name: Dance of Peace
Desc: The flute has been an important instrument for Chinese music since the Han Dynasty. By the Tang Dynasty, it had already become an indispensable high-pitched instrument both in and out of the court. In Dunhuang murals, vivid flute players can be found with both hands holding the flutes while focusing on their breath and fingering. They dance while playing, creating a peaceful and tranquil image of the Pure Land.

Name: Hanying Ascends
Desc: Another Apsara in Mogao Cave 320 seems to be light and carefree with her arms above her head while chasing and playing around. It shows the desire to break the constraints of the mortal world in pursuit of spiritual freedom in Buddhist art and a vivid image of peace and happiness in the Pure Land.

Name: Flying Apsaras
Desc: The Flying Apsaras are a classic symbol of Dunhuang murals. Mogao Cave 320 has a painting in which an Apsara scatters flowers while looking back. In Buddhist culture, the act of scattering flowers is considered holy way of spreading the Dharma and blessings. Besides, the way the Apsara looks back infuses a concern and longing for the mortal world. Together they form an ethereal picture with a touch of compassion.

Name: Nine-Colored Deer
Desc: A horizontal sequential comic strip on the west wall in Mogao Cave 257 depicts the story of a kind, beautiful nine-colored deer, a previous incarnation of Buddha Shakyamuni, saving a drowning person and the betrayal, the salvation, and the king's final awakening and protection of kindness behind it, demonstrating the Buddhist teachings on karma and compassion.

Name: Blue Bird
Desc: According to legends, the Blue Bird has a close relationship with Xiwangmu, the Queen Mother of the West, and serves as her messenger between the mortal and immortal worlds. In a mystical, vivid painting of Mogao Cave 249, the Blue Bird holds its head high while dancing with other celestial animals.

Name: Winged Horse
Desc: In a mural in Mogao Cave 249, a winged horse dances along with the celestial beings and winged figures, which adds a mythical charm to the mural while demonstrating a perfect combination of Buddhist art and elements of traditional Chinese mythology.

Name: Treasure-Guarding Dragon
Desc: Although flying dragons are commonly seen in Dunhuang murals, sitting dragons are rarely seen. The solemn, powerful treasure-guarding dragons in Yulin Grotto 25 are quite unique among depictions of the Metteya Sutra transformation scene.

Name: Nine-Story Building
Desc: The Nine-Story Building refers to a wooden structure outside Mogao Cave 96 that protects the murals and statues in the cave. Originally built as a four-story structure in the second year of the Tang Dynasty's Yan Zai reign, it has gone through generations of reconstructions and extensions before finally transforming into the current nine-story structure during the Republic of China period. Built on the mountainside, the Nine-Story Building has a height of 45 meters, surpassing all its traditional counterparts in terms of structure and scale, and is the tallest building in Mogao Caves. The Nine-Story Building connects to the cave that holds a giant Maitreya Buddha, forming a signature site of Mogao Caves.

Name: The Three Hares
Desc: The Three Hares are commonly seen in the caisson ceiling of domed ceiling caves. Among the 18 extant caves with the Three Hares motif in Dunhuang, the one in Mogao Cave 407 is the most representative. In the center of an eight-petal lotus, three hares sharing three ears are chasing one another in an infinite circle. From the perspective of Buddhist culture, the three hares symbolize the infinite cycle of 'the previous life,' 'the present life,' and 'the future life,' demonstrating the Buddhist concept of reincarnation. The concept also resonates with the Taoist belief of 'three lives,' making the pattern a symbol of cultural fusion.

Name: Flute: Heavenly Music Without Instruments Being Played
Desc: If you take a look at the Amitabha Sutra Transformation Painting on the north wall of Mogao Cave 321, you will find a variety of musical instruments around the elegant flying Apsaras and clouds in the sky. These instruments with ribbons float in the sky and give out melodious music without being played by anyone, demonstrating the profound artistic accomplishment and rich creative thinking of the ancient painters.

Name: Pipa: Heavenly Music Without Instruments Being Played
Desc: If you take a look at the Amitabha Sutra Transformation Painting on the north wall of Mogao Cave 321, you will find a variety of musical instruments around the elegant flying Apsaras and clouds in the sky. These instruments with ribbons float in the sky and give out melodious music without being played by anyone, demonstrating the profound artistic accomplishment and rich creative thinking of the ancient painters.

Name: Auspicious Clouds I
Desc: The auspicious clouds are a symbol of happiness, harmony, and holiness in traditional Chinese culture, while in Dunhuang murals, they're used to depict the ascension of Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, flying Apsaras, and other celestial beings and the peaceful atmosphere in the heavens and the Buddhist realm. For example, in the mural on the north wall of Mogao Cave 3, Guanyin Bodhisattva is stepping on the auspicious clouds, whereas in the mural in Cave 61, Mount Wutai is surrounded by auspicious clouds, creating a mystical and heavenly image.

Name: Auspicious Clouds II
Desc: The auspicious clouds are a symbol of happiness, harmony, and holiness in traditional Chinese culture, while in Dunhuang murals, they're used to depict the ascension of Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, flying Apsaras, and other celestial beings and the peaceful atmosphere in the heavens and the Buddhist realm. For example, in the mural on the north wall of Mogao Cave 3, Guanyin Bodhisattva is stepping on the auspicious clouds, whereas in the mural in Cave 61, Mount Wutai is surrounded by auspicious clouds, creating a mystical and heavenly image.

Name: Mountain Rocks I
Desc: The mountain rocks are a reproduction of natural sceneries by ancient artists. Judging from mountains depicted in Mountains and Yaksha in Cave 254 and The Story of Sumati in Cave 257, the Dunhuang murals of the Northern Wei Dynasty have improved based on the triangle-like mountains in paintings from Han and Jin Dynasties. Smooth lines were abandoned. Instead, the artists used the combination of a straight line and a zigzag line to form a mountain, making it look more vivid and natural.

Name: Mountain Rocks II
Desc: The mountain rocks are a reproduction of natural sceneries by ancient artists. Judging from mountains depicted in Mountains and Yaksha in Cave 254 and The Story of Sumati in Cave 257, the Dunhuang murals of the Northern Wei Dynasty have improved based on the triangle-like mountains in paintings from Han and Jin Dynasties. Smooth lines were abandoned. Instead, the artists used the combination of a straight line and a zigzag line to form a mountain, making it look more vivid and natural.
